This article discusses what magnesium is, the benefits of this mineral, and where to buy magnesium supplements online. Magnesium is vital for many important bodily functions, [such as](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Magnesium-HealthProfessional/) - protein synthesis - supporting muscles and nerves - regulating blood sugar It is widely available in many different kinds of food, such as leafy greens and whole grains. Manufacturers may add the mineral to fortified foods such as cereals. People should [always aim to consume enough](https://www.eatright.org/food/vitamins-and-supplements/types-of-vitamins-and-nutrients/magnesium) magnesium through food, as food also contains a variety of other nutrients essential to health, including vitamins, protein, and other minerals. However, many people do not eat enough magnesium-rich foods and may benefit from taking a supplement. Benefits of magnesium [include](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Magnesium-HealthProfessional/) - helping maintain [blood pressure](/articles/270644) - reducing the risk of [heart disease](/articles/237191)and [stroke](/articles/7624) - reducing the risk of [type 2 diabetes](/articles/317462) - helping increase bone mineral density in postmenopausal women There is also [evidence](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5637834/) [muscle cramps](/articles/what-causes-cramps), [migraine](/articles/148373), [insomnia](/articles/9155), [anxiety](/articles/323454), and depression. People should ensure that the amount of magnesium in the supplement is enough for their requirements. - Type of magnesium. Some types of magnesium are easier for the body to absorb, such as magnesium aspartate, chloride, lactate, and citrate. Magnesium is generally safe to consume. The NIH states that the upper tolerable limit of magnesium is [350 mg](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Magnesium-HealthProfessional/) Studies show that higher doses are safe to consume. For example, [500 mg of magnesium](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5637834/) The NIH also says that consuming too much magnesium through food does not pose a health risk to most people as the kidney filters the excess mineral in the urine. However, the main side effects of having too much magnesium supplementation include [diarrhea](/articles/158634), [nausea](/articles/what-causes-nausea), and abdominal cramping. Very high doses of magnesium, often in the form of antacids, can cause magnesium toxicity. This is more common in people who consume around 5000 mg of magnesium with antacids. Symptoms of magnesium toxicity include: [low blood pressure](/articles/159609) - nausea [vomiting](/articles/vomiting) - facial flushing - difficulty urinating [ileus](/articles/322149) - depression [lethargy](/articles/lethargy) If a person does not receive treatment for magnesium toxicity, they will experience: - muscle weakness - irregular heartbeat - very low blood pressure - difficulty breathing [cardiac arrest](/articles/cardiac-arrest) People with [kidney failure](/articles/327300) are more likely to develop magnesium toxicity as their kidneys cannot filter the excess magnesium in the urine.
